lessons.name: Using Ten Fingers
lessons.text: now that you know how to type with all ten fingers, lets work on your speed and then move on to other keys.

lessons.name: Increase Speed
lessons.text: if you want your typing speed to increase, you must first focus on your accuracy.

lessons.name: Practice
lessons.text: practice makes perfect. every time you repeat this lesson, your speed will increase.

lessons.name: Don't Look Down
lessons.text: remember the first and only rule of typing, never ever look at the keyboard while typing.

lessons.name: Practice R Hand
lessons.text: look, only you join him. only you look him up.

lessons.name: Staring at Screen
lessons.text: when we stare at a screen we tend to blink less. that is bad for the eyes because they can get dry.

lessons.name: Take Breaks
lessons.text: make sure to look away from the computer every fifteen minutes, and take a five minute break every hour.

lessons.name: Look Away
lessons.text: once you have finished typing this lesson, look away from the computer for a few short seconds before looking at the results.

lessons.name: Active Breaks
lessons.text: because sitting at a computer is the exact opposite of exercise, you should take a more active break every hour or so.

lessons.name: Practice L Hand
lessons.text: as tree grew grass waved grass were watered trees were fed

lessons.name: Muscle Memory
lessons.text: it usually takes a few weeks of practice to build the muscle memory needed to type fast.

lessons.name: Good Posture
lessons.text: good posture helps improve our concentration, letting you work longer and harder. it also prevents sore muscles.

lessons.name: Adjust Your Screen
lessons.text: look straight ahead. make sure your eyes look directly into your monitor the same way you would look at someone across the table from you.

lessons.name: Trust Yourself
lessons.text: once you are more comfortable with the keyboard, you may turn off the virtual hand guides by using the settings at the top of the page.

lessons.name: Practice R Hand
lessons.text: my opinion on him. pumpkin oil, milk, ink, mill.

lessons.name: University
lessons.text: Your second home in your life is your university, were you meet different friends. and make strong relationship

lessons.name: Words
lessons.text: look ahead straight ahead make sure keyboard memory weeks concentration improve posture good usually practice

lessons.name: Brain Power
lessons.text: as you type, your brain remembers each word as a pattern of keystrokes. this allows you to type the same words without thinking about how to type each character.

lessons.name: Repeat Lessons
lessons.text: to see how it works lets type the next sentence five times. i am glad. i am glad. i am glad. i am glad. i am glad.

lessons.name: Never Stop
lessons.text: to make sure you do not go back to typing with two or four fingers, make sure to revisit these lessons a few times during the coming week.

lessons.name: No Peeking
lessons.text: if you learn to never look at your keyboard when typing, the computer will feel like a part of your body with your mind in full control.

lessons.name: Practice L Hand
lessons.text: streets are safe better see a fast car race served a tea we rest

lessons.name: Home Row
lessons.text: placing your fingers on the home row will help you learn to type faster and build the correct muscle memory. now try doing it with your eyes closed or while you look at the screen.

lessons.name: Moving Forward
lessons.text: from the home row all other keys are just a short distance away. as you practice, you will build speed because you hardly have to move your fingers from one key to the next.

lessons.name: Type Correctly
lessons.text: while it may feel easier at first, hunting and pecking at letters makes it harder to concentrate when you type. you also type slower and build the wrong muscle memory.

lessons.name: Train Your Muscles
lessons.text: just like a basketball player trains their muscles so they focus on the game, you can train your muscles to type without much thinking about it.

lessons.name: Practice R Hand
lessons.text: jolly puppy look up on you. lumpy pumpkin only you.

lessons.name: Virtual Guide
lessons.text: whenever you are unsure which finger you should use to type a certain letter, take a look down at the virtual hands. they will guide you.

lessons.name: Bumps on J & F
lessons.text: your index fingers should always find their way back to f and j by feeling for those bumps. it takes some practice but it will help you get better.

lessons.name: Become a Pro
lessons.text: fast typists forget about the keyboard and do not even realize their fingers are at work. once you practice more you will feel the same way too.

lessons.name: Cacao Tree
lessons.text: Chocolate comes from the fruit of the cacao tree which is commonly found in the deep tropical areas of the Americas. The most commonly found type of the plant first came from the Amazon basin.

lessons.name: Wooden Churches
lessons.text: Almost fifty amazing wooden churches stand all over Slovakia, a small country in the heart of Europe. They are all wood without a single nail.

lessons.name: Vasco da Gama
lessons.text: Lisbon, the capital city of Portugal, is home to the longest bridge in Europe. The Vasco da Gama Bridge in Lisbon is seventeen kilometers or ten and a half miles long.

lessons.name: Solar System
lessons.text: The solar system is the Sun and all the objects in orbit around it. The Sun is orbited by planets, asteroids, comets, and other things.

lessons.name: Dogs
lessons.text: Dogs were the first animals ever to be domesticated. They are usually playful, friendly, and listen to humans. Thirty million dogs in the United States are registered as pets.

lessons.name: Spaces in English
lessons.text: A thousand years ago, the English language did not put spaces between its words. It made writing faster, but readers had to guess where each word began.

lessons.name: Puppies
lessons.text: Puppies develop very quickly during their first three months, particularly after their eyes and ears open and they are no longer completely dependent on their mother.

lessons.name: Singing Whales
lessons.text: Whales love to sing. They use songs as a form of communication, and also just for fun. After a period of time, they get bored of the same song and begin to sing a different tune.

lessons.name: Africa
lessons.text: Africa is the second largest continent in the world in both size and population. Madagascar is not only a popular animated comedy film, but also the largest island in Africa.

lessons.name: Polyps
lessons.text: Polyps attach themselves to surfaces like docks and bulkheads. There they grow, until late spring when they become millions of new jellyfish. These jellyfish are sting ready by summer.

lessons.name: Photosynthesis
lessons.text: All living things need energy to live, and energy comes from food. Plants can not eat food like animals, so they must get their energy in a different way. They use photosynthesis.

lessons.name: Astronauts
lessons.text: The name astronaut comes from the Greek words for star and sailor. Astro means star, and naut refers to sailors. Astronauts orbiting Earth can see up to sixteen sunrises and sunsets every day.

lessons.name: Cultural Diversity
lessons.text: Cultural diversity is having different cultures respect each others differences. It could also mean the variety of human societies or cultures in a specific region, or in the world as a whole.

lessons.name: Sharks
lessons.text: Sharks do not have a single bone in their bodies. Rather than bones, sharks have a skeleton made of cartilage. Cartilage is the same type of tough, flexible tissue that makes up human ears and noses.

lessons.name: Biology
lessons.text: Like all sciences, biology uses the scientific method. This means that biologists must be able to show evidence for their ideas, and that other biologists must be able to test the ideas for themselves.

lessons.name: Typewriters
lessons.text: Typewriters, unlike modern keyboards, use large mechanical parts to press ink down on paper. If someone pressed down keys that were next to each other on the typewriter, the parts would sometimes get jammed.

lessons.name: Pandas
lessons.text: The giant panda, or panda, is a bear native to central western and southwestern China. It is easily recognized by its large, distinctive black patches around the eyes, over the ears, and across its round body.

lessons.name: Biologist
lessons.text: People who study biology are called biologists. Biology looks at how animals and other organisms behave and work, and what they are like. Biology also studies how organisms react with each other and the environment.

lessons.name: Keyboard Layout
lessons.text: Keyboards look as if someone jumbled the letters around to make it harder to find each key. In fact, the QWERTY layout was very carefully designed to prevent the mechanical parts of typewriters from jamming together.

lessons.name: Super Power
lessons.text: Our muscles have an amazing way of letting our bodies do difficult things without even thinking about it. It is called Muscle Memory. When you practice typing, you are building muscle memory so you can type without having to focus on it.

lessons.name: Mongolia's Capital
lessons.text: Ulaanbaatar is the capital of Mongolia and its largest city. As a nomadic city, the capital used to move three times a year. With just four people per square mile, Mongolia is the least densely populated country on Earth.

lessons.name: Chinese Art
lessons.text: Arts and crafts have a long history in China. Thousands of years ago the Chinese were some of the first people to use silk, jade, bronze, wood, and paper to make art. The artistic writing called calligraphy was invented in China.

lessons.name: Pandas, Part 2
lessons.text: Giant pandas live in the temperate zone bamboo forests of central China. They are among the best recognized but rarest animals in the world. Pandas have come to symbolize endangered species and conservation efforts.

lessons.name: Placement Test Basic Level 2
lessons.text: The QWERTY keyboard looks as if someone jumbled the letters around to make it harder to find each key. In fact, this layout was very carefully designed to prevent the mechanical parts of typewriters from jamming together.

lessons.name: San Francisco
lessons.text: San Francisco, officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the financial, cultural, and transportation center of the San Francisco Bay Area, a region of 7.15 million people which includes San Jose and Oakland.

lessons.name: Spoken Languages
lessons.text: There are over 6,000 languages spoken in the world today, many of which are spoken by fewer than a few hundred people. The top 10 or 12 languages, however, make up the vast majority of all of the speakers in the world.

lessons.name: New Mexico
lessons.text: New Mexico became a state on January 6, 1912 and became the 47th state accepted into the United States. The state capital is Santa Fe. The population is 1,819,046 and most of the people live in the biggest city, Albuquerque.

lessons.name: Earthquake
lessons.text: There are dozens of tectonic plates below the surface of the Earth that move continuously and slowly past each other. When the plates squeeze or stretch, huge rocks form at their edges and the rocks shift with great force, causing an earthquake.

lessons.name: Hurricane
lessons.text: A hurricane is a huge storm. It can be up to 600 miles across and have strong winds spiraling inward and upward at speeds of 75 to 200 mph. Each hurricane usually lasts for over a week, moving 10 to 20 miles per hour over the open ocean.

lessons.name: Tectonic Plates
lessons.text: The Pacific Ocean is currently shrinking due to plate tectonics, while the Atlantic Ocean is increasing in size, by roughly an inch per year or 2 to 3 cm/yr on 3 sides, roughly averaging 0.2 square miles or 0.52 square kilometers a year.

lessons.name: Aphelion
lessons.text: July 4th is the 185th day of the year or 186th in leap years in the Gregorian calendar. There are 180 days remaining until the end of the year. Aphelion, the point during the orbit of the Earth when it is furthest from the Sun, occurs around this date.

lessons.name: Mark Twain Quote
lessons.text: Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things that you did not do than by the ones you did do, so throw off the bowlines, sail away from safe harbor, catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore, Dream, Discover. Mark Twain

lessons.name: Galaxies
lessons.text: Scientists calculate that there are at least 100 billion galaxies in the observable universe, each one brimming with stars. On a very large scale, they form a bubbly structure, in which vast sheets and filaments of galaxies surround gargantuan voids.

lessons.name: Trains
lessons.text: A train is a connected series of vehicles for rail transport that moves along a track to transport cargo or passengers from one place to another. The track usually consists of two rails, but might also be a monorail or maglev guideway.

lessons.name: Lightning Rods
lessons.text: Benjamin Franklin carried out extensive electricity research in the 18th century, inventing the lightning rod amongst his many discoveries. Lightning rods protect buildings in the event of lightning by conducting lightning strikes through a grounded wire.

lessons.name: Weather
lessons.text: Weather is the state of the atmosphere at any time, including things such as temperature, precipitation, air pressure, and cloud cover. Daily changes in the weather are due to winds and storms. Seasonal changes are due to the Earth revolving around the sun.

lessons.name: Newton's First Law
lessons.text: The first law of motion says: if a body is at rest it remains at rest or, if it is in motion, it moves with uniform velocity, until it is acted on by a resultant force. An object continues to do whatever it happens to be doing unless a force is exerted upon it.

lessons.name: Silverback
lessons.text: An adult male gorilla is called a silverback because of the distinctive silvery fur growing on their back and hips. Each gorilla family has a silverback as leader who scares away other animals by standing on their back legs and beating their chest.

lessons.name: Manhattan
lessons.text: The oldest part of New York City, the island of Manhattan, still has its original Lenape Native American name. Although native people such as the Lenape and Canarsees had lived there for many thousands of years, New York City was first explored by Europeans in the 1500s.

lessons.name: Inside Hurricanes
lessons.text: Hurricanes gather heat and energy through contact with warm ocean waters. Evaporation from the seawater increases their power. Hurricanes rotate in a counterclockwise direction around the eye in the Northern Hemisphere, and clockwise direction in the Southern Hemisphere.

lessons.name: Native Americans
lessons.text: Native American tradition says that they were always in America. Most of the scientific evidence suggests that their ancestors came from Asia in prehistoric times, either by foot over a land bridge or using ancient boats. This would have happened more than 20,000 years ago.

lessons.name: Astronomy
lessons.text: Astronomy is the study of everything outside the atmosphere of the Earth. It studies celestial objects such as stars, galaxies, planets, moons, asteroids, comets and nebulae and processes such as supernovae explosions, gamma ray bursts, and cosmic microwave background radiation.

lessons.name: Speed of Light
lessons.text: The speed of light in a vacuum, usually denoted by c, is a physical constant important in many areas of physics. Its value is 299,792,458 meters per second, a figure that is exact since the length of the meter is defined from this constant and the international standard for time.

lessons.name: Wind Farms
lessons.text: A.W. Hawaii Wind is a Texas company. It is proposing two offshore floating wind farms. Each would consist of 50 turbines that would generate about 400 megawatts of energy. The wind farms would be placed more than 10 miles offshore. They would float in waters about a half a mile deep.

lessons.name: Spanish New Year
lessons.text: In Spain and many Latin American countries they celebrate New Year by eating 12 grapes at midnight, just as the new year begins. The tradition consists of eating a grape with each bell strike at midnight on December 31. According to the tradition, this leads to a year of prosperity.

lessons.name: Wild Dogs
lessons.text: Wild dogs travel in groups called packs. These packs are very social, working together to hunt, raise pups, and share food. They have been known to take care of sick or injured pack members. Wild dogs are different than stray dogs. A stray dog was once a pet, but a wild dog has never been domesticated.

lessons.name: Tornadoes
lessons.text: The USA has more tornadoes than any other country in the world, averaging around 1,200 a year. This is due largely to the unique geography of the Midwest which forms an area known as Tornado Alley. The highest recorded tornado wind speed is 302 miles per hour, on May 3, 1999 in Bridge Creek, Oklahoma.

lessons.name: Chicago
lessons.text: Chicago is the largest city in Illinois. It is the third largest city in the United States, although it used to be the second largest. Chicago is next to Lake Michigan, one of the five Great Lakes. In the 2000 census, almost 2,900,000 people lived there, with six million more people living nearby.

lessons.name: Placement Test Basic Level 2
lessons.text: A train is a connected series of vehicles for rail transport that move along a track to transport cargo or passengers from one place to another.

lessons.name: Energy formula
lessons.text: Energy equals mass multiplied by (*) the speed of light squared (^2). The multiplication sign is usually left out, giving e is equal to mc squared.

lessons.name: Formula
lessons.text: E^2 is equal to (m0c^2)^2 plus (pc)^2 where #1 E represents the energy of a particle #2 m0 represents the mass of the particle when it is not moving #3 p represents the momentum of the particle when it is moving #4 c represents the speed of light.

lessons.name: Math
lessons.text: The c^2 in the equation stands for the speed of light squared. To square something means to multiply it by itself. The speed of light is approximately 3 * 10^8. If we square this, we get 9 * 10^16 meters^2/seconds^2 or to 90,000,000,000,000,000 meters^2/seconds^2.

lessons.name: Mention
lessons.text: A mention (also known as @replies or tagging, not to be confused with metadata tags or hashtags #) is a means by which a blog post references or links to a user profile. This may be done as a matter of getting the attention of (or drawing attention to) another user of a social networking or blogging service.

lessons.name: Tigers
lessons.text: Tigers vary in size depending on their subspecies. Siberian tigers are the largest. Males can grow to be 6 feet (1.8 meters) long (body length) and weigh about 500 pounds (230 kg). Females are a bit smaller. The record weight for males is claimed to be 700 pounds (318 kg), but this cannot be confirmed.

lessons.name: Natural Diamonds
lessons.text: Most natural diamonds are formed at high temperature and pressure at depths of 140 to 190 kilometers (87 to 118 mi) in the mantle of the Earth. Minerals containing carbon provide the carbon source, and the growth occurs over periods from 1 billion to 3.3 billion years (25% to 75% of the age of the Earth).

lessons.name: Canada
lessons.text: Canada is the second largest country in the world by total area (Russia is the largest). It features the longest coastline in the world, stretching 202080 kilometers (125570 miles). Canada shares the longest land border in the world with the United States, totaling 8891 kilometers (5525 miles).

lessons.name: Driverless Cars
lessons.text: Fully autonomous vehicles (driverless cars) currently exist in prototype (Google has developed a driverless car). These cars are expected to be available commercially in the near future. Autonomous cars could help to reduce the number of vehicles needed on the road and dramatically increase safety.

lessons.name: Scandinavia
lessons.text: Scandinavia is a geographical and cultural region in Northern Europe, which consists of Norway, Sweden, and Denmark. There is a completely different language spoken in each country (Norwegian, Danish, and Swedish). However, all three languages have Germanic roots and are considered mutually understandable.

lessons.name: Air
lessons.text: Air is the clear gas which living things breathe. It has no color or smell. The air around us is a mixture of many gases and dust particles. It is a mixture of about 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, 0.9% argon, 0.04% carbon dioxide, and very small amounts of other gases. There is also an average of about 1% water vapor.

lessons.name: France
lessons.text: France is the third largest country by size in Europe at 248,573 m2 (643,801 km2). The highest point in France is Mont Blanc at 15,771 feet (4,807 m) high, which is also one of the highest points in Europe. The greatest symbol of the country, the Eiffel Tower, was going to be demolished in 1909, but luckily was repurposed as a radio antenna.

lessons.name: Tallest Building
lessons.text: Currently, the tallest building in the world is the Burj Khalifa, standing at 829.8 m (2,722 ft) tall! The Burj Khalifa is located in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Previous to its completion, the tallest building in the world was Taipei 101, located in Taipei, Taiwan. Taipei 101 is 509.2 m (1,671 ft) tall.

lessons.name: Sleeping Beauty
lessons.text: Sleeping Beauty (1959) is an American animated movie produced by Walt Disney Productions and released to movie theaters by Buena Vista Distribution. Sleeping Beauty earned (approximately) $7.7 million in box office rentals. Its production costs totaled $6 million, making it the most expensive Disney movie to that date.

lessons.name: Hashtag
lessons.text: A hashtag, written with a # symbol, is used to index keywords or topics on Twitter. This function was created on Twitter, and allows people to easily follow topics they are interested in. People use the hashtag symbol (#) before a relevant keyword or phrase to categorize their Tweets and for Twitter searches.

lessons.name: French Crepes
lessons.text: France is the birthplace of crepes. On almost every street corner you can find a small kiosk serving crepes. There are savory crepes (such as with cheese and ham) or sweet ones (such as with chocolate and fruit). The aroma around crepe shops is so good that it is difficult to pass by without stopping to get a bite.

lessons.name: Russia
lessons.text: Russia is the largest country in the world by area. It covers more than 1/9 of the land area of the Earth. Russia has the longest railway in the world, the Trans Siberian Railway. To travel from one end to the other would take around 6.5 days! It has connected the cities of Moscow and Vladivostok since 1916.

lessons.name: Ampersand
lessons.text: The origin of the ampersand (&) can be traced back to the Latin word et, meaning and. The E and T that make up this word were written together to form a ligature (a character consisting of two or more joined letters). Writing this way saved time, with one letter flowing seamlessly into the next; a form of cursive writing.

lessons.name: Coconut
lessons.text: Coconuts come from the coconut palm tree which grows throughout the tropics and subtropics. The coconut palm (Cocos nucifera) can grow up to 30 m (98 ft) tall and the leaf fronds can grow to be 4 to 6 m (13.1 to 19.7 ft) long. Coconut milk has a high fat content of around 17%, but is low in sugar.

lessons.name: Costa Rica
lessons.text: Costa Rica only takes up 0.03% of the surface of the planet but holds 5% of its biodiversity! There are over 130 species of fish, 220 species of reptiles, 1,000 species of butterflies, 9,000 species of plants, 20,000 species of spiders, and 34,000 species of insects! More than 25% of Costa Rican land is protected national parks and refuges.

lessons.name: Jeanne d'Arc
lessons.text: A famous story known by all French citizens, and many others around the world, is about 19 year old Joan of Arc during the Hundred Years War. Due to her leadership and courage, the French army won many battles. However, Joan was eventually captured by the Burgundians.

lessons.name: Metabolism
lessons.text: The makeup of our bodies changes as we age. The proportion of muscle decreases, and the proportion of body fat increases. This slows metabolism, or the rate at which the body converts food into energy. As a result, it is easier for middle aged people to put on weight, even if they do not change how they eat or how much they exercise.

lessons.name: Country Music
lessons.text: Country music has its roots and beginnings in folk music. The old cowboy and pioneer songs of the American frontier were popular in the early twentieth century, and so were arrangements of pop music songs by rural (or rural sounding) performers. Country musicians also adapted new musical instruments, like the Hawaiian steel guitar.

lessons.name: Formal Education
lessons.text: Formal education is usually in school, where a person may learn basic, academic, or trade skills. Small children often attend a nursery school or kindergarten but often formal education begins in elementary school and continues with secondary school. Post secondary education (or higher education) is usually at a college or university.

lessons.name: Frogs
lessons.text: Frogs are amphibians of the order Anura. There is no fundamental difference between frogs and toads, and they are not classified separately. This is because the toad lifestyle, with its dry, rough skin, is an adaptation to living in drier habitats. The toad form has evolved a number of times independently, an example of convergent evolution.

lessons.name: Red-Crowned Parrot
lessons.text: In 2011, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced that the red-crowned parrot warranted federal protection. They too acknowledged that the birds' homes have been lost, and that they've been poached for the pet trade. They want the birds to be protected by being on America's official list of endangered species.

lessons.name: Eclipse of 2017
lessons.text: During the eclipse of 2017, the Moon's shadow raced over the Earth's surface at more than 2,000 miles per hour. A roughly 65-mile-wide zone, called the path of totality, offered the best viewing. Stars and planets came out, and the Sun's corona glowed in a perfect circle around the dark side of the Moon.

lessons.name: Thomas Jefferson
lessons.text: Thomas Jefferson, the third of ten children, was born on April 13, 1743 in Shadwell, Virginia into a planter family. His parents were Peter and Jane Jefferson. He had six sisters and three brothers. At 9 years old Jefferson began studying Latin, Greek, and French; he also learned to ride horses, and began to study nature.

lessons.name: Food Allergies
lessons.text: Food allergies are fairly common amongst adults and even more so among children. Around 2% of adults and 8% of children suffer from some type of food allergy where the immune system makes a mistake and thinks a certain food protein is dangerous and attacks it. Common food allergies are to seafood and peanuts.

lessons.name: King Kong
lessons.text: King Kong is a fictional character, a giant movie monster resembling a gorilla, that has appeared in several movies since 1933. These include the groundbreaking 1933 movie, the film remakes of 1976 and 2005, as well as various sequels of the first two films. The character has become one of the world's most famous movie icons.

lessons.name: Great Eclipse
lessons.text: In 2017, the mainland U.S. will experience its first solar eclipse in almost 30 years. At the time of writing, the eclipse is scheduled to occur on August 21, 2017. Some are calling it the Great American Eclipse because the moon's shadow will cross twelve states from Oregon in the Pacific Northwest to South Carolina in the Southeast.

lessons.name: Great Depression
lessons.text: The timing of the Great Depression varied across nations, but in most countries it started in 1929 and lasted until the late 1930s or early 1940s. It was the longest, most widespread, and deepest depression of the 20th century. In the 21st century, the Great Depression is commonly used as an example of how far the world's economy can decline.

lessons.name: Jovian Planets
lessons.text: The four outer planets, or gas giants, collectively make up 99% of the mass known to orbit the Sun. Jupiter and Saturn are each many tens of times the mass of the Earth and consist overwhelmingly of hydrogen and helium. Uranus and Neptune are far less massive (<20 Earth masses) and possess more ice in their makeup.

lessons.name: Independence Day
lessons.text: Independence Day in the United States of America is celebrated on the 4th of July. On this day, the Declaration of Independence was approved by Congress. This document declared that the 13 colonies were a new nation, and independent from the British Empire.

lessons.name: Carbon Dioxide
lessons.text: When humans burn fossil fuels like gas and oil, a gas called carbon dioxide is released into the air. There, it reacts with water vapor. Some of the carbon falls back to Earth as rain. This causes the level of carbon in the ocean to rise. The carbon prevents oysters and clams from growing thick, hard shells. It also hurts coral.

lessons.name: Diesel Engines
lessons.text: Cars with diesel engines tend to have better fuel economy, which means they can travel further on a single tank of gas. The drawback is that diesel engines emit gases called oxides of nitrogen, which pollute the environment. NOx can lead to acid rain, smog, and ozone. High levels of NOx in the atmosphere can make it hard to breathe.

lessons.name: Stay-at-home Dads
lessons.text: Fathers are more involved in their children's lives today than in the past, says a new report from the American Academy of Pediatrics. It draws on census data, surveys, and academic research. Among the findings, the number of stay-at-home dads has increased by more than 60%. There were 98,000 in 2003 and 159,000 in 2012, according to the U.S. Census.

lessons.name: The US President
lessons.text: The president of the United States of America is both the head of state and head of the government. The office of president was created in the United States Constitution in 1788. The first president took office in 1789. The president serves as chief executive and is in charge of the executive branch of the United States government.

lessons.name: Mexican Parrots
lessons.text: In Mexico, bird habitats have been destroyed as forests and trees have been cut down to make room for farms and ranches. Right now, scientists are working to get an accurate count of the population. The last study, published in 1994, estimated the parrot population to be 3,000 to 6,500 birds. That's down from more than 100,000 in the 1950s.

lessons.name: Gold Rush
lessons.text: In 1776, colonists from Spain established a fort at the Golden Gate and a mission named for Francis of Assisi. The California Gold Rush of 1849 propelled the city into a period of rapid growth, increasing the population in one year from 1,000 to 25,000, and thus transforming it into the largest city on the West Coast at the time.

lessons.name: Pluto
lessons.text: Pluto is the 2nd most massive known dwarf planet in the solar system and the 10th most massive body observed directly orbiting the Sun. Originally classified as the 9th planet from the Sun, Pluto was recategorized as a dwarf planet and plutoid due to the discovery that it is 1 of many large bodies in the newly charted Kuiper belt.

lessons.name: Mexico
lessons.text: First inhabited more than 10,000 years ago, the cultures that developed in Mexico became one of the cradles of civilization. During the 300 year rule by the Spanish, Mexico became a crossroad for the people and cultures of Europe, Africa, and Asia. The government of Mexico actively promotes shared cultural traits in order to create a national identity.

lessons.name: The Moon
lessons.text: The Moon is in synchronous rotation with Earth. This means it always shows Earth the same face with its near side marked by dark volcanic maria that fills the spaces between the crustal highlands and impact craters. It is the brightest object in the sky after the Sun, although its surface is actually dark.

lessons.name: Oil
lessons.text: The word oil is used for many different kinds of liquids. Oil usually does not mix with water. Some oils are made from plants and used in foods and for cooking. Some varieties of plant oils are African palm, maize (corn), olive, peanut, soy, and sunflower. Other kinds of oil are made from crude oil (petroleum) which comes from under the ground.

lessons.name: Life of Plants
lessons.text: Plants take water from soil through their veins, which are called xylem. The water goes to their leaves, which take carbon dioxide from the air. Carbon dioxide mixes with the water. Energy from the sun helps this process along and turns the combination into a sugar called glucose. Glucose is plant food, it gives plants energy to grow.

lessons.name: Iron
lessons.text: It might only take you a few minutes to finish a meal but it takes your body around 12 hours before it has completely digested the food. The human body needs iron to help perform a number of important functions. Iron helps carry oxygen to parts of your body in the form of hemoglobin. Not having enough can lead to iron deficiency and symptoms such as weakness and fatigue.

lessons.name: Refrigeration
lessons.text: Persians invented a type of evaporative cooler known as a Yakhchal around 400 BCE. It was a dome-shaped object used as a means of refrigeration. The items meant to be kept cool were stored in the subterranean part of this structure and since it had this subterranean space as well as heat-resistant materials, it was capable of storing ice or foods in the hot desert year-round.

lessons.name: Muhammad Ali
lessons.text: Muhammad Ali, the three time world heavyweight boxing champion, never forgot his roots. He returned to his old neighborhood and visited high school classmates even after becoming one of the most recognizable men in the world. Muhammad Ali was born and raised in Kentucky, where he started boxing at the age of 12.

lessons.name: Music Production
lessons.text: There are many more people working on pop music than those that are seen on stage or in the video. These people include the studio, production, distribution and retail staff, each of which help the musicians to record with extensive quality control, and sell it to the stores and finally to people.

lessons.name: Placement Test 50WPM
lessons.text: In 2011, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced that the red-crowned parrot warranted federal protection.

lessons.name: Australia
lessons.text: There are roughly six times more sheep in Australia than there are people. Australia is a relatively wealthy country which makes it an attractive place to live for many people around the world. Sydney is one of the eight capital cities in Australia. It is also Australia's largest city, followed by Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide.

lessons.name: Robots
lessons.text: Robots have many uses. Factories use industrial robots to do hard work quickly and without mistakes. The military uses robots to find and get rid of bombs. If a mistake is made on a battlefield, the robot is damaged or destroyed, which is better than a person being killed. There are also domestic robots that can vacuum or cut grass.

lessons.name: Windmills
lessons.text: A windmill converts the energy of the wind into rotational energy. Wind power stations use the wind to turn a turbine which turns a magnet inside a coil. The wind has kinetic energy (movement energy) which is changed into mechanical energy by the blades on the turbine. The turbine then turns a generator which creates electrical energy (voltage).

lessons.name: Ancient China
lessons.text: China has the world's oldest continuous civilization. There is archaeological evidence of this that is over 5,000 years old. China also has one of the world's oldest writing systems, and is viewed as the source of many major inventions. China is home to some of the oldest artwork in the world. Statues and pottery are some classic examples.

lessons.name: Gas Giants
lessons.text: The four farthest planets in the solar system, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, are called gas giants. This is because they are large planets that are mostly made of gas, such as hydrogen and helium, with a relatively small rocky core. Even though they are made of gas, they have significantly more mass than the terrestrial planets.

lessons.name: Water
lessons.text: Water is a molecule made of 2 hydrogen atoms and 1 oxygen atom. Its chemical formula is H2O. Water has surface tension, so a little bit of water makes drops rather than spreading out over the surface. Though a human being can survive for up to a week without food, they can only survive for a day or two without water.

lessons.name: Citation
lessons.text: When you do research, always remember to write down the places you find information. This is called citing, or making a citation. A good idea is to bookmark all of the pages with information you want to use so you don't lose track of your sources. Then, when you are ready to make your bibliography, you'll be prepared.

lessons.name: The Sun
lessons.text: Although we think of our Sun as a unique celestial body, it is actually one of trillions of stars in the universe. Some estimates for stars similar to the Sun in just the Milky Way galaxy are as high as 7 billion. If this number is correct, there could be over one trillion stars that are roughly the same as our Sun in the universe.

lessons.name: Black Hole
lessons.text: A black hole is a region of spacetime from which nothing, not even light, can escape. The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass will deform spacetime to form a black hole. Most black holes are made when a supergiant star dies.

lessons.name: Your Communities
lessons.text: How much time do you spend thinking about the communities you belong to? If you're like most of us, probably not enough. That's because we take them for granted. Whether it's our circle of friends, the clubs we've joined or even the sports teams we play for, we tend to forget we belong to many different communities at the same time.

lessons.name: Marie Curie
lessons.text: The first woman to win a Nobel Prize was Marie Sklodowska Curie, who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903 with her husband, Pierre Curie, and Henri Becquerel. Curie is also the only woman to have won multiple Nobel Prizes; in 1911, she won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Curie's daughter, Irene Joliot-Curie, won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1935.

lessons.name: Marine Life
lessons.text: While there are hundreds of thousands of known marine life forms, there are many that are yet to be discovered. Scientists suggest that there could actually be millions of marine life forms out there. We've only explored about 5% of Earth's oceans! The oceans cover 71% of the Earth's surface and contain 97% of the Earth's water.

lessons.name: Birds
lessons.text: Different types of birds eat different foods. Most birds are carnivorous meaning that they eat meat. Some examples are fish, small reptiles, insects, and mice. Birds of prey eat mammals and other birds. Many birds such as parrots and finches live on seeds and fruit.

lessons.name: River
lessons.text: A river is a stream of water that flows through a "channel" (or passage) in the surface of the ground. The passage where the river flows is called the riverbed and the earth on each side is called a riverbank. A river begins on high ground or in hills or mountains and flows down from the high ground to the lower ground due to gravity.

lessons.name: New Zealand
lessons.text: New Zealand was the first country in the world to allow women to vote in 1893. It has been recognized as the world's most peaceful country. New Zealanders refer to themselves as Kiwis, which probably dates back to World War I when New Zealand soldiers acquired the nickname. The New Zealand dollar coin features a kiwi bird on one side.

lessons.name: Indonesia
lessons.text: Indonesia is the largest archipelago in the world, and is made up of 18,000 separate islands. Indonesia is home to the most odorous flower on Earth, often referred to as the corpse flower. It can grow to an average height of 2 meters (6.5 ft). When it blooms, it releases a foul odor comparable to rotten meat, which can be smelled from half a mile away.

lessons.name: George Washington
lessons.text: Washington was a delegate to the First Continental Congress, which was created by the Thirteen Colonies to respond to various laws passed by the British government. Washington was chosen by the Second Continental Congress to be the commanding general of the Continental Army. Washington led the army from 1775 until the end of the war in 1783.

lessons.name: Crowdfunding
lessons.text: Crowdfunding is becoming a popular option for early-stage startups. It generates buzz among potential customers. It may be an especially attractive option in the current market, with venture funding harder to come by. But multimillion-dollar success stories remain rare. Crowdfunding isn't expected to replace venture funding anytime soon.

lessons.name: Background Actors
lessons.text: Background actors are also known as "extras". They are often called the unsung heroes of TV shows, movies, music videos, and commercials. They are men, women, and sometimes children who get paid $8-$12 an hour. They make city streets look busy, hospitals look crowded, and parties look fun.

lessons.name: Laws of Robotics
lessons.text: A robot may not injure a human being, or through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm. A robot must obey orders given to it by human beings, except where such orders would conflict with the first law. A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the first or second law.

lessons.name: Olive Oil
lessons.text: While grapes are an important part of many Mediterranean cultures, nothing beats the importance of olives in Spain. The cultivation of olives and the production of olive oil have deep roots in Spanish history. About 45% of the world's olive oil is produced in Spain! Each year, the average Spaniard consumes around 14 liters (or 3.7 gallons) of olive oil.

lessons.name: Germany
lessons.text: Germany is one of the largest and most powerful economies in Europe. After the United States, Germany is the second most popular country for migration in the world. When John F. Kennedy visited Berlin in June, 1963, he infamously said, "Ich bin ein Berliner", which also happens to translate in German as "I am a jelly donut".

lessons.name: Trees
lessons.text: The leaves of trees are green most of the time, but they can come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. Leaves take in sunlight and use water and food from the roots to help the tree grow and reproduce. Trees and shrubs take in water and carbon dioxide and give out oxygen. As a tree grows, it may produce growth rings.

lessons.name: Flowers
lessons.text: A flower is a part of a plant. Flowers are also called the bloom or blossom of a plant. The plant grows on a stalk, a thin node, which supports the flower. Flowers have petals. Inside the petals are the parts which produce seeds. Flowers are the reproductive structure of flowering plants, which are plants of the division Magnoliophyta.

lessons.name: Placement Test 55WPM
lessons.text: There are roughly six times more sheep in Australia than there are people. Australia is a relatively wealthy country which makes it an attractive place to live for many people around the world.

lessons.name: Pocket Monsters
lessons.text: Pokemon (abbreviated from Pocket Monsters) is a Japanese anime series. It is part of the Pokemon media franchise which is owned by Nintendo. It has been brought to many other places, including North America, Europe, and Australia. The series is about Pokemon and the humans (trainers) that catch and train them to battle each other.

lessons.name: California
lessons.text: California is a big power in American culture as well as the business life of the nation. Many of the great changes in technology and law came from California, and the state pays more to the U.S. government than it gets back. It also has some of the country's largest cities, such as Los Angeles, San Diego, San Jose, and San Francisco.

lessons.name: Drones
lessons.text: Drone flights will be permitted only during the day and at twilight. Drone industry officials have long complained that these time restrictions precluded a great many uses. Among them are some search and rescue operations. Some agricultural operations are best done after dark as well. Operators can seek waivers to many of these restrictions.

lessons.name: Parts of Trees
lessons.text: A tree is a tall plant with a trunk and branches made of wood. It can live for many years. The four main parts of a tree are the roots, the trunk, the branches, and the leaves. A single tree has many roots. The roots of a tree are usually underground. One case for which this is not true are the roots of the mangrove tree.

lessons.name: Amelia Earhart
lessons.text: "The most difficult thing is the decision to act, the rest is merely tenacity." Amelia Earhart was the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. In 1937, Earhart disappeared over the central Pacific Ocean near Howland Island when attempting to make a circumnavigational flight around the globe.

lessons.name: Telephone
lessons.text: Alexander Graham Bell was the first person to patent the telephone, in 1876. Early telephones were wired directly to each other and could only talk to the phone that they were connected to. Later, telephone exchanges allowed connecting to other telephones. During the 20th century the machines that made the connections were automated.

lessons.name: Korean Language
lessons.text: The Korean alphabet, also known as Hangul, is the native alphabet of the Korean language. It was created by Sejong the Great during the Joseon Dynasty in 1443, and is now the official script of both South Korea and North Korea. There are 14 basic consonants and 10 basic vowels. Letters that have similar sounds also have similar shapes.

lessons.name: Seawater
lessons.text: Seawater cannot be drunk safely because it has high salinity, or concentration of salt. Seawater is also called salt water. Both people and animals often live near rivers, because they need water to survive. The water in a river is called fresh water. Fresh water comes from rain or snow and it can usually be drunk safely, unless it has been polluted.

lessons.name: Birds
lessons.text: Birds are found on every continent of the world. Birds of different types can live in freezing cold environments, and others can live in hot deserts. Birds live in forests, in grasslands, on cliff faces, in river banks, on stony seashores, down mine shafts, and under the roofs of houses.

lessons.name: John Lennon
lessons.text: "Life is what happens to you while you're busy making other plans." John Lennon was an English singer & songwriter, and one of the founders of the Beatles. The Beatles were one of the most influential bands of their time. Lennon also had a solo career with such famous songs as "Imagine" and "Give Peace a Chance".

lessons.name: Walt Disney
lessons.text: Walt Disney worked very hard to run his movie studio. He liked to spend weekends with his two daughters. The family liked going to carnivals and fairs. Mr. Disney wanted to build a place that had all of the fun of the traveling fairs where parents and children could ride together. That is how Mr. Disney got the idea for Disneyland.

lessons.name: Indy 500
lessons.text: One famous attraction of Indiana is the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, which is where the Indy 500 is held every year. The Indy 500 is one of the most famous car races in the United States. The Indianapolis Motor Speedway is not actually in Indianapolis. It is in a town called Speedway, which is completely surrounded by Indianapolis.

lessons.name: Washington D.C.
lessons.text: At first, Washington D.C. was made up of a piece of Virginia located south of the Potomac River and a piece of Maryland located north of the Potomac River. In 1847, Virginia's land was returned to it. This area is now part of Arlington County. Since 1847, all of Washington D.C. is on the north side of the Potomac River.

lessons.name: Election
lessons.text: In the United States, the presidential election is held every four years on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November. You help choose your state's electors when you vote for President because when you vote for your candidate you are actually voting for your candidate's electors. This is part of a system called the Electoral College.

lessons.name: Henry Ford
lessons.text: "Whether you think you can or you think you can't, you're right." Henry Ford was an American industrialist, the founder of the Ford Motor Company, and the sponsor of the development of the assembly line technique of mass production. Ford developed and manufactured the first automobile that many middle-class Americans could afford.

lessons.name: U.S. Constitution
lessons.text: The United States Constitution makes the President the Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces and lists powers given to the president. George Washington was the first President of the United States from 1789 to 1797. He was also the commander in chief of all American forces during the American Revolutionary War.

lessons.name: Moon's Surface
lessons.text: The Moon appears to have more craters and scars than Earth because it has a lot less natural activity. The Earth is constantly reforming its surface through earthquakes, erosion, rain, wind, and plants growing on the surface. The Moon, however, has very little weather or activity that would alter its appearance.

lessons.name: Library
lessons.text: A library is not a bookstore (a store that sells books). Many places have a public library, where anybody can join if they live in the area. With a library card, people can borrow books and take them home for several weeks. It does not cost money to get a library card at most public libraries.

lessons.name: U.S. Constitution
lessons.text: The United States Constitution makes the President the Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces and lists powers given to the president. George Washington was the first President of the United States from 1789 to 1797. He was also the commander in chief of all American forces during the American Revolutionary War.

lessons.name: Coconut Pickers
lessons.text: Thailand has been raising and training pigtailed macaques, a species of monkey common to the area, to pick coconuts for around 400 years. Coconut farmers in Sri Lanka, Malaysia, India and other countries in the region sometimes rely on monkeys, too. The monkeys attend a training school where they learn to pick coconuts.

lessons.name: Thoreau
lessons.text: "Go confidently in the direction of your dreams. Live the life you have imagined." Henry David Thoreau was a 19th century American essayist, poet, and philosopher. Among his lasting contributions are his writings on natural history and philosophy, in which he anticipated the methods and findings of ecology and environmental history.

lessons.name: Recycling
lessons.text: Recycling is turning the materials from trash into something new. Glass, paper, plastic, and metals such as aluminum and steel are all commonly recycled. Dead plants and some kitchen trash can be recycled through composting. Recycling is different than reusing, which is where old things, such as clothes, are donated or given a new use instead of being thrown out.

lessons.name: Dolphins
lessons.text: There are two species in the Delphinus genus, the Short-beaked Common Dolphin (Delphinus delphis), and the Long-beaked Common Dolphin (Delphinus capensis). Some studies say there is a third species, the "Arabian Common Dolphin" (Delphinus tropicalis), which has a long, thin beak and is found in the Indian Ocean and the Red Sea.

lessons.name: Disneyland
lessons.text: The first Disneyland opened on July 17, 1955. It is one of the most popular theme parks in the world. Disneyland celebrated its golden anniversary on July 17, 2005. In 2001, the area around the park expanded into a resort with 3 hotels, a shopping and dining area called Downtown Disney and a second theme park, Disney's California Adventure.

lessons.name: Reasons to Recycle
lessons.text: Recycling reduces the amount of raw materials and energy used to make things. Most of the time, it takes less energy to recycle trash than to throw it away, The Economist says. Recycling helps minimize the amount of garbage that ends up in trash dumps around the world.

lessons.name: Light Year
lessons.text: A light year is the distance that light travels through empty space in one year. Since the speed of light is about 300,000 km per second (about 186,000 miles per second), then one light year is about 10 trillion kilometers (about 6 trillion miles). A light year is not a length of time. Light years are used in astronomy because the universe is huge.

lessons.name: Freedom of Speech
lessons.text: Few countries with "free speech" let everything be said. For example, the U.S. Supreme Court said that it is against the law to shout "fire" in a crowded theater if there is no fire because it might cause people to panic. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights also says that it is not okay to cause national, racial, or religious hatred.

lessons.name: Lake Okeechobee
lessons.text: In the center of southern Florida is a very big lake called Lake Okeechobee. It is the seventh largest freshwater lake in the United States and the second largest freshwater lake entirely within the lower 48 states. Okeechobee is 730 square miles, about half the size of the state of Rhode Island, and is very shallow for a lake of its size.

lessons.name: Romeo and Juliet
lessons.text: Romeo and Juliet is one of the most famous plays written by William Shakespeare. It tells a story of two young people who love each other eternally, but have to overcome numerous obstacles to be together. They both come from noble families, however, the Capulets and the Montagues are mortal enemies. The story is set in the beautiful Italian city of Verona.

lessons.name: Police Dogs
lessons.text: There are dogs that are trained to smell for diseases in the human body or to find bombs or illegal drugs. These dogs sometimes help police in airports or other areas. Sniffer dogs (usually beagles) are sometimes trained for this job. Dogs have even been sent by Russians into outer space. The first dog sent to space was named Laika.

lessons.name: Alexander G. Bell
lessons.text: "When one door closes, another door opens. But we so often look so long and so regretfully upon the closed door, that we do not see the ones which open for us." A quote by Alexander Graham Bell, the brilliant scientist, inventor, and engineer credited with patenting the first telephone in 1876. He refused to have a telephone in his study.

lessons.name: Placement Test More Symbols
lessons.text: "When one door closes, another door opens. But we so often look so long and so regretfully upon the closed door, that we do not see the ones which open for us." A quote by Alexander Graham Bell

lessons.name: Oliver Twist
lessons.text: Oliver Twist is Charles Dickens's second novel. It tells a story of an orphan boy who was captured by thieves and forced to work with them. The book is often referred to as a social novel, as it draws the reader's attention to child labor and the presence of orphan children on the streets.

lessons.name: Red Pandas
lessons.text: Red pandas are native to the Himalayas and southwestern China. The English word for red panda is "Firefox" which is where the popular web browser gets its name from. Many people think that the Firefox logo is a fox, but the truth is that the logo is actually a red panda. The browser was created in 2002 and its full name is Mozilla Firefox.

lessons.name: Illinois
lessons.text: Marquette and Joliet are given credit for being the first Europeans to find the state of Illinois. Illinois became a state on December 3, 1818. Its state insect is the Monarch Butterfly, its state tree is the white oak, its state flower is the violet, its state bird is the cardinal, and its state animal is the white-tailed deer.

lessons.name: Music Structure
lessons.text: Music is sound that has been organized using rhythm, melody, or harmony. If someone bangs saucepans while cooking, it makes noise. If a person bangs saucepans in a rhythmic way, they are making a simple type of music. Blues is played by singing, using the harmonica, or the acoustic guitar. Jazz musicians use instruments such as the trumpet and saxophone.

lessons.name: Climate
lessons.text: Climate is the average weather usually taken over a 30 year time period for a particular region and time period. Climate is not the same as weather, but rather, it is the average pattern of weather for a particular region. Weather describes the short-term state of the atmosphere, including temperature, precipitation, air pressure, and cloud cover.

lessons.name: War and Peace
lessons.text: Leo Tolstoy is a Russian author who wrote one of the most famous Russian novels in the history of literature called War and Peace. The book describes life in Russia in the 19th century during the wars with Napoleon. There are almost 600 characters mentioned in the story, but the main characters are members of 4 noble families.

lessons.name: Prehistoric Art
lessons.text: Cave paintings are painted drawings on cave walls or ceilings, mainly of prehistoric origin. Evidence suggests that they were not merely decorations of living areas since the caves in which they have been found do not have signs of ongoing habitation. They are also often located in areas of caves that are not easily accessible.

lessons.name: Car Races
lessons.text: Almost as soon as automobiles were invented races of various sorts were organized, with the first recorded as early as 1867. Many of the earliest events were reliability trials, aimed at proving these new machines were a practical mode of transport. Soon, they became an important way for competing makers to demonstrate their machines.

lessons.name: Martial Arts
lessons.text: Martial arts are codified systems and traditions of combat practices, which are practiced for a variety of reasons including self-defense, military and law enforcement applications, and mental and spiritual development. In addition, they are practiced for entertainment and the preservation of a nation's intangible cultural heritage.

lessons.name: Communities
lessons.text: Online communities are now a normal part of our everyday lives. The internet has not only changed the way we form communities, but the tools we use to communicate, too. People around the world use social media sites to keep in touch with family and meet new people, or connect with friends using online games on their phones or computers.

lessons.name: Music Everywhere
lessons.text: Music is found in every known culture, past and present, varying widely between times and places. Since all people of the world, including the most isolated tribal groups, have a form of music, it may be concluded that music is likely to have been present in the ancestral population prior to the dispersal of humans around the world.

lessons.name: Pandas, Part 3
lessons.text: Giant pandas are about the size of an American black bear. They are about 3 feet (91 cm) tall at the shoulder when they are standing on all four legs. Pandas are typically about 6 feet (180 cm) long. In the wild, males can weigh up to 250 pounds (110 kg). Females usually weigh less than 220 pounds (100 kg).

lessons.name: Cave Paintings
lessons.text: Some theories hold that cave paintings may have been a way of communicating with others, while other theories ascribe a religious or ceremonial purpose to them. The paintings are remarkably similar around the world, with animals being common subjects. Humans mainly appear as images of hands.

lessons.name: Ancient Music
lessons.text: The prehistoric age is considered to have ended with the development of writing, and with it, by definition, prehistoric music. "Ancient music" is the name given to the music that followed. The oldest known song was written in cuneiform, dating to 3400 years ago from Ugarit. It was deciphered by Anne Draffkorn Kilmer.

lessons.name: Anglo-Saxons
lessons.text: The area now called England was first inhabited by modern humans during the Upper Palaeolithic period, but it takes its name from the Angles, one of the Germanic tribes who settled the area during the 5th and 6th centuries. The term Anglo-Saxon stems from the Angles and the Saxons, another tribe that inhabited the area during that time.

lessons.name: Newton's Law
lessons.text: Newton's second law of motion is: the resultant force is equal to mass times acceleration. This law says that acceleration is dependent on the forces acting upon an object and the mass of the object. Therefore if the force increases, acceleration increases, and the more mass the object has, the acceleration decreases.

lessons.name: Health Care
lessons.text: Health care is the preservation of mental and physical health by preventing or treating illnesses through services offered by the health profession and its staff. Health care includes all reasonable and necessary medical aid, medical evaluations, and medical services. The right to health care is considered a human right.

lessons.name: Industry Awakes
lessons.text: The Industrial Revolution was a period from the 18th to the 19th century where major changes in agriculture, manufacturing, mining, transportation, and technology had a profound effect on the socioeconomic and cultural conditions of the times. It began in the United Kingdom, then spread throughout Europe, North America, and eventually the world.

lessons.name: Static Electricity
lessons.text: When an electric charge builds up on the surface of an object it creates static electricity. You have probably experienced static electricity in the form of a small electric shock, which is what happens when an electric charge is quickly neutralized by an opposite charge. Opposite charges attract each other. Positive charges repel each other, as do negative charges.

lessons.name: Words per Minute
lessons.text: Words per minute (WPM) is a measure of input or output speed. For the purposes of WPM measurement, a word is standardized to five characters or keystrokes. The average person types around 40 words per minute. However, professional typists type a lot faster. On average, professional typists can type upwards of 65 to 80 WPM.

lessons.name: Divine Comedy
lessons.text: The Divine Comedy is an epic poem written by Dante Alighieri. It is divided in three parts, with Inferno being the most famous one. The word "comedy" in the title does not mean that the poem is funny, rather that it has a positive ending. Dante has to travel through 9 concentric circles of suffering to be saved.

lessons.name: Elephant's Trunk
lessons.text: An elephant's trunk is able to sense the size, shape, and temperature of an object. An elephant uses its trunk like a human uses its hands. It can grab food and put it in its mouth to feed itself. It can also suck up water and pour it into its mouth or spray itself on a hot day. Elephants can use their trunks like a snorkel to breathe in deep water.

lessons.name: Healthy Diet
lessons.text: A healthy diet provides the body with essential nutrition: fluid, adequate essential amino acids from protein, essential fatty acids, vitamins, minerals, and adequate calories. The requirements for a healthy diet can be met from a variety of plant-based and animal-based foods.

lessons.name: Nefertiti
lessons.text: Nefertiti was the primary wife of the Pharaoh Akhenaten, who unsuccessfully tried to change the religion of Egypt. Akhenaten was then succeeded by a pharaoh referred to as Smenkhare. Some scientists believe Smenkhare and Nefertiti are the same person. Many think the queen changed her name during her rule. She reigned during the wealthiest period of Ancient Egypt.

lessons.name: Teachers
lessons.text: Teachers direct the education of students and might draw on many subjects, including reading, writing, mathematics, science, and history. In many countries, teachers must obtain certifications or a university degree in order to qualify for a position. Teachers around the world work hard to help students learn.

lessons.name: Atoms
lessons.text: The basic unit of an element is called an atom. An atom is the smallest building block that you can cut an element into without the element breaking down into a lighter element. Two ways that atoms can be broken down are through nuclear fission or radioactive decay. A chemical compound is a substance made up of 2 or more elements.

lessons.name: Olympics History
lessons.text: The Olympic Games were a series of athletic competitions among representatives of city-states and one of the Panhellenic Games of Ancient Greece. They were held in honor of Zeus, and the Greeks gave them a mythological origin. The first Olympic Games were held in 776 BC, and they continued to be celebrated when Greece came to be under Roman rule.

lessons.name: Olympics Ceremony
lessons.text: During the celebration of the games, an Olympic Truce was enacted so that athletes could travel from their cities to the games in safety. The prizes for the victors were olive leaf wreaths or crowns. The games became a political tool used by city-states to assert dominance over their rivals. The Olympics also featured religious celebrations.

lessons.name: GM Foods
lessons.text: Genetically modified foods, or GMOs, are foods produced from organisms that have had changes introduced to their DNA using methods of genetic engineering. Genetic engineering techniques allow for the introduction of new traits as well as greater control over traits than previous methods such as selective breeding and mutation breeding.

lessons.name: Michael Jordan
lessons.text: "I've missed more than 9000 shots in my career. I've lost almost 300 games. 26 times I've been trusted to take the game winning shot and missed. I've failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed." Michael Jordan is a retired professional basketball player. He played 15 seasons with the Bulls and Wizards.

lessons.name: Our Solar System
lessons.text: There are eight planets in the solar system. From closest to farthest from the Sun, they are: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. A fun way to remember the order of the planets is to use a mnemonic device: My Very Excellent Mother Just Served Us Noodles. Each letter represents the name of one planet.

lessons.name: Volcano
lessons.text: A volcano is an opening, typically a mountain, in the Earth's surface that opens downward to a pool of hot liquid rock, or magma. When pressure builds up underneath the volcano, eruptions can occur. When a volcano erupts, gas, ash, and magma can shoot through the opening. When magma leaves a volcano, it is known as lava.

lessons.name: Frogs
lessons.text: Frogs can live on land and in fresh water. They cannot survive in salt water. Their development is by metamorphosis. They hatch from eggs as tadpoles, which are laid by a female frog. The eggs are called frogspawn. Tadpoles have tails and gills. When they grow up, they lose their tails and gills and grow four long legs.

lessons.name: Australia
lessons.text: Australia is a country in the Southern Hemisphere between the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean. Its official name is the Commonwealth of Australia. Australia is the sixth biggest country in the world by landmass. The Australian emblem is a flower called the Golden Wattle. Australia is also the smallest continent in the world.

lessons.name: Japan
lessons.text: When Japanese meet, they traditionally bow instead of shake hands. The lower the bow, the deeper respect it shows. Sumo is recognized as the national sport of Japan, although it isn't the most popular one. Sumo is a wrestling sport where a wrestler tries to force another wrestler out of a circular ring. Sumo is practiced professionally in Japan.

lessons.name: Exercise
lessons.text: The benefits of exercise for all ages have been known since antiquity. Marcus Cicero, around 65 BC, stated, "It is exercise alone that supports the spirits, and keeps the mind in vigor." Regular exercise has been shown to help high blood pressure, obesity, heart disease, diabetes, and depression, among other conditions.

lessons.name: Milky Way
lessons.text: There are many other systems like our solar system in the universe. Each star has the potential to have a planetary system. There are more than 200 billion stars in the Milky Way galaxy. The Sun is the star found at the center of our solar system. At around 1,392,000 kilometers (865,000 miles) wide, the Sun's diameter is about 110 times wider than Earth's.

lessons.name: J.K. Rowling
lessons.text: "Rock bottom became the solid foundation on which I rebuilt my life." J.K. Rowling is a British novelist and screenwriter. She is best known as the author of the very popular fantasy book series Harry Potter. The Harry Potter book series consists of 7 books, which were turned into 8 movies.

lessons.name: Internet Size
lessons.text: Over the years, the web has grown bigger and bigger. Today, there are tens of trillions of pages on the Internet. That's so many pages that if you were to print them out and stack them all, you would have a pile that would reach from Earth to the Moon at least a dozen times. All of these pages are connected to each other through links.

lessons.name: Human Posture
lessons.text: The general concept of human posture refers to the "carriage of the body as a whole, the attitude of the body, or the position of the limbs." Good posture helps improve our concentration, letting us work longer and harder. It also prevents sore muscles, leading us to feel happier and healthier both at and away from the computer.

lessons.name: Italy
lessons.text: Italy is a country in Europe and one of the founding countries of the European Union. It is a peninsula located in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea. Thanks to its shape, it is often referred to as the Boot. Italy is said to have more masterpieces per square mile than any other country. Italy's capital, Rome, is home to the famous Colosseum.

lessons.name: Reading Speed
lessons.text: Some studies suggest that people tend to read as much as 10% slower from a screen than from paper. Reading text from a computer screen can negatively impact your vision in the long term. The blue light emitted from devices such as computers or mobile phones has been proven to diminish the quality of sleep and cause headaches.

lessons.name: New Mexico
lessons.text: New Mexico is a state in the United States of America. It is part of the American Southwest and is bordered by Texas to the east, Oklahoma to the northeast, Colorado to the north, and Arizona to the west. The northwest corner of the state also touches Utah. This area is known as the Four Corners because four states meet there.

lessons.name: Notifications
lessons.text: A modern notification system is a combination of software and hardware that provides a means of delivering a message to a set of recipients. For example, notification systems can send an email when a new topic has been added to Wikipedia.

lessons.name: US Territories
lessons.text: There are 50 states in the United States of America, with Hawaii being the last one to join in 1959. There are independent US territories believed to be part of the 50 states, such as Puerto Rico and Guam, which is a very common misconception. They are self governing territories with locally elected governors and territorial legislatures.

lessons.name: Power of Water
lessons.text: Plants and animals (including people) are mostly water inside. The human body is made up of 60% to 70% water. All plants and animals need water to live. Water gives a medium for chemical reactions to take place, and is the main part of blood. Water helps blood carry nutrients from the stomach to all parts of the body to keep the body alive.

lessons.name: Stay Healthy
lessons.text: Here is a quick recipe for staying healthy: take a break every 15 minutes to give your eyes and body a rest! Get out of your chair; maybe even take a short walk. If you have a window in the room, take a look outside. Stretch your back, neck, and arms, and reach for the sky. Take a break, get active, and stay healthy!

lessons.name: Copernicus
lessons.text: Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus was the first scientist to suggest that the Earth was not the center of the universe. He proposed a model that placed the Sun in the center in his publication in 1543. It is said that Copernicus did not want to publish his theses for fear of the reaction he would receive.

lessons.name: Man's Best Friend
lessons.text: Dogs can smell and hear very well, but cannot see colors very well. Dogs are sometimes referred to as "man's best friend" because they are kept as domestic pets, are usually loyal, and like being around humans. Dogs can be taught many skills and often have jobs helping people, such as service dogs, guard dogs, and police dogs.

lessons.name: Little Women
lessons.text: Little Women is a book by Louisa May Alcott published in 1868. The story is about the fictional March sisters, who lived in the time of the American Civil War. Their father served as a chaplain in the Union Army. The author was inspired by her own childhood experiences when writing the book. The book was made into a drama film in 1994.

lessons.name: Social Media I
lessons.text: Most social media sites share some of the basics. You create a profile which tells other users who you are. You get to pick an avatar, your online likeness in the form of a picture or drawing. You'll probably meet trolls, or people who are there to annoy others. You'll have tools to flag or report inconsiderate and improper content.

lessons.name: Dental Hygienist
lessons.text: A dental hygienist is a dental professional registered with a dental association in their country. Dental hygienists often work alongside dentists to provide full oral health care. Very few dental hygienists work independently. Their training focuses on the prevention and treatment of oral disease, such as cavities, gum disease etc.

lessons.name: Disneyland Park
lessons.text: Mr. Disney's friends thought the idea of making an amusement park was a crazy one. After selling land that he loved very much in Palm Springs to help pay for the park, the building of Disneyland began in 1954. He also used a weekly television show called Disneyland to make people want to see his park. In only one year, Disneyland Park was open.

lessons.name: Hummingbirds
lessons.text: Some birds that eat mainly seeds feed their young on insects. A few types of birds eat green plants, but only one species lives on leaves. Hummingbirds and Honeyeaters live on the nectar or honey in flowers. Birds come in many sizes from the Bee Hummingbird that is only 60 mm long to the ostrich which stands 2.5 meters high.

lessons.name: Flame
lessons.text: A flame is the visible, gaseous part of a fire. A flame is a mixture of reacting gases and solids emitting visible, infrared, and sometimes ultraviolet light. The frequency spectrum of the emitted light depends on the chemical composition of the burning material, or fuel, and the intermediate reaction products.

lessons.name: Healing Arts
lessons.text: Healing arts programs began at a handful of hospitals in the 1960s but have skyrocketed in the past decade or so. Research has shown that art can be therapeutic for people during stressful times. A 2015 Review: of past studies in The Lancet found that listening to music before, during or after surgery helped recovery.

lessons.name: Maps
lessons.text: The earliest maps were probably simple sketches in dirt. Eventually, ancient people began to carve maps on stone and clay tablets. The oldest surviving clay map, dated to around 2,300 B.C., comes from ancient Mesopotamia. Other ancient maps have been found around the world. These were typically focused on the area around the map-makers and did not attempt to map the whole Earth.

lessons.name: Social Media II
lessons.text: There are many different types of social media. The most common are personal networks like Facebook, where you connect with other people. There are media sharing sites like Instagram where you post pictures. There are also forums, where people meet to chat about specific topics, and social publishing, like KidBlog where you post longer articles.

lessons.name: Nursing
lessons.text: Nursing is an extremely popular profession in the United States, with around 3 million registered nurses nationwide. Nurses provide care and support for individuals and their families. They work alongside physicians and follow their directions precisely to ensure a quick recovery of each patient. Their ultimate goal is to improve our quality of life.

lessons.name: Pure Water
lessons.text: While relatively small quantities of water are observed by humans to be colorless, pure water has a slight blue color. The blue tint of water is an intrinsic property and is caused by selective absorption and scattering of white light. Impurities dissolved or suspended in water may give water different colored appearances.

lessons.name: Placement Test 66WPM
lessons.text: Italy is a country in Europe and one of the founding countries of the European Union. It is a peninsula located in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea. Thanks to its shape, it is often referred to as the Boot.

lessons.name: Postnatal Brain
lessons.text: Mental abilities, as well as other abilities such as motor control, memory, and general reasoning are served equally by the two hemispheres. Until very recently medical experts believed that humans were born with all of the brain cells they would ever have. However, we now know that new neurons can be created in the postnatal brain.

lessons.name: What Computers Do
lessons.text: Computers are curious things. They hold your favorite stories, but they aren't books. They take you to faraway places, but they aren't airplanes. They whisk you through history, but they aren't time machines. With the push of a button, computers help you play, learn, share, and communicate. These days, computers affect your life in countless ways.

lessons.name: Butcher
lessons.text: Butcher is one of the professions which are not very popular with the new generation. A butcher is the person who prepares and sells meat. They prepare cuts of meat and poultry for sale in retail. Nowadays, it is very hard to find a place to get a fresh cut of meat which does not come from a giant chain grocery store.

lessons.name: Brazil
lessons.text: Brazil is the largest Portuguese-speaking country in the world. It is home to the Amazon Rainforest which produces more than twenty percent of the Earth's oxygen.
